content:
✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Easy to understand,
Could even be a CoC !

You may work with truncated time (or rounded) and DO worry about fractions OR switch difficulty to easy.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Good puzzle! Challenging enough but still easy to solve. Perfect!

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Everything seems fine to me !
Thank you for your contribution :)

Hi hypers,

All your tests are very specific as they all happen at 8:00:00 + a multiple of 4 minutes.
This should be specified in the statement, otherwise the player may spend unnecessary time to deal with the other cases. Also other cases are not well defined, for example true time 8:01:00 AM would be associated to observed time 8:01:59.75 AM.

Thanks for your comments.
This is my first contirbution so I may be missing a lot of points.
As you've mentioned the tests avoid dealing with fractions of a second. This is done on purpose. If you imagine a real world railway station clock this makes sense as it is highly unlikely to see the accuracy of 0.5s or even 0.25s when refering to a physical clock (being analog or digital).
Initially I wanted to state in the goal that true time should be rounded to the nearest second. But then I decided that providing the format in the constraints and the example would suffice.
If you think this is not enough I can add this requirement (rounding to whole seconds) which should still pass all tests.
I'd prefer not to go with the complex cases like in your example because of the reasons laid above.
Many thanks.

Thanks for your help in making it more clear.
Un grand merci!

Thanks for support!
Probably it should be changed to easy.

If you add that time should be rounded, then it should be tested. I guess that's not what you are looking for.

Maybe you can add the following note to the statement:
"Tests are specifically designed to avoid dealing with fractions of seconds".

Good point. Thanks.
How about this caveat?
"You don't need to worry about fractions of a second (all tests are guaranteed to have whole seconds for both observed and true times)"
